html:
NEW YORK, Nov 11 (IFR) - IFR is hosting a US ECM Roundtable titled “SPACs at a Crossroads” on Wednesday November 17 at 12:30pm. The event will assess the regulatory landscape and funding conditions for SPAC IPOs and PIPEs. Please take a moment to register for the event.

We are also inviting banks to pitch for the 2021 IFR Awards . ECM award categories cover IPOs, follow-ons, CBs and SPACs completed throughout the year in the US and LatAm.

Rivian Automotive’s stunning debut today (see next item for more) highlights how much value ECM can create, but it doesn’t take away from the fact that most offerings right now are not “must-own”.

There remains a huge amount of tension between bankers’ desire to push out as many deals as possible before the end of the year and the quality of demand and buyside concern about how much upside is left in this market.

Some fear the banks will keep pushing until the market finally breaks down altogether. It would not be the first time that happened.

This sense of an unsustainable deal scramble is reinforced by the fact that most of this week’s heavy deal flow has been compressed into the first three days of the week because of tomorrow’s Veterans Day federal holiday (the SEC is closed).

Tonight alone brings at least 13 deals for $2.4bn of proceeds, including five IPOs, seven follow-ons and one CB (plus whatever SPACs price). Including these, the first three days of this week will have seen 25-30 deals priced (and 35 including SPACs), though apart from Rivian and Hertz Global (which fell again in its second Nasdaq session today), most are on the smaller side of things.

Today’s IPOs delivered good performance, not just Rivian and Expensify (more below) but even the 40% downsized NYSE offering from Brazilian software engineering firm CI&T. Its shares popped more than 50% intraday before closing their debut session up 20.8%.

Notwithstanding that, companies returning with follow-ons are facing the prospect of steep discounts to satisfy hedge fund-heavy books, while some of the stocks that shed the most value in today’s broader market downdraft were 2021 IPOs highly vulnerable to late-year profit-taking.

Falling more than 15% today were Poshmark, Monday.com and Agrify, as well as highly fancied names such as Toast, Affirm and Global-E Online (that said, Affirm was rebounding big-time after-hours after the release post-close of its Q3 numbers).

“I think many bankers saw the move in the market last week and decided this was a great time to bring deals, so we are seeing a lot of them this week and probably next week too,” one senior ECM banker said.

The action is about to grind to a halt, at least until next week.

Among the few transactions launched post-close was a $350m CB for additive manufacturing firm 3DSystems (an unregistered/144A deal, therefore not requiring SEC vetting).

In a big week for the firm, Morgan Stanley also slipped in a circa-$575m block sell-down (a 13% stake) in organic food maker Hain Celestial, representing nearly all of sponsor Engaged Capital’s remaining stake. Hain Celestial shares are up 20% this year and have tripled since late 2018.

Looking ahead to next week, six IPOs are scheduled (the biggest being the $500m-plus IPO of Kindercare) but the deal mix could turn more secondary-heavy as IPO launches dry up to avoid a clash with Thanksgiving in the following week.

Automatic

With a certain air of inevitability, shares of Rivian Automotive debuted in the triple digits today as many investors saw little choice but to chase a slice of a company that may or may not be the next Tesla but only has to deliver some of the latter’s EV success to turn into a great investment over time.

After upsizing the offering by 13% to 153m shares and pricing at $78.00 or $4.00 above the top of the $72–$74 range for $11.9bn of proceeds, Rivian opened at $106.75 for a 36.9% gain.

It struggled to hold those gains in a tough tech tape, closing its first session at $100.73, up 29% for the day.

It was still a big win for the Morgan Stanley/Goldman Sachs/JP Morgan-led syndicate, not least because the direct order entry/hybrid auction format will likely mean fees from the deal will favor the top of the syndicate.

“We are super-pleased that this went so well, particularly for this time of the year,” one syndicate member said. “These large $5bn–$10bn deals are incredibly challenging to get to trade well in any situation.

“We didn’t push price to the maximum so that there was nothing left for the market, which is important, especially for a company that will need to raise more capital to fund their business plan.”

At the opening mark, the 12-year-old maker of EV pickup trucks, SUVs and delivery vans secured a $90bn-plus market cap from what is the biggest IPO in the US and globally this year, as well as the biggest US deal since Alibaba’s 2014 NYSE debut. On Refinitiv data, Rivian also ranks as the 15th biggest IPO of all time.

That’s an amazing milestone (and a sign of the times) for a company that is only just starting to deliver its first vehicles and collect revenue, and has the job in front of it to deliver on 54,000 pre-orders over the next few years as well as build 100,000 vans for no-doubt demanding customer Amazon (and Rivian is not exactly a household name like most of the other biggest IPOs of all-time).

Some are forecasting the company will be producing one million vehicles by the end of the decade (a suspiciously round number), requiring it to build more plants beyond the retooled former Mitsubishi factory in Normal, Illinois from which it is producing cars now.

The sheer size of the Rivian offering also highlights the massive capex needs the company will have over time, in contrast to big IPOs like Facebook or Twitter that were just about hoarding cash for strategic reasons or funding the tax bills of employees.

Central to the success of the deal was the massive $5bn cornerstone investment outlined on the cover of the filing, including some of the biggest names on the Street/in the Valley as a measure of their confidence in founder RJ Scaringe.

As for the rest of the book, bankers said there was broad-based support, including from tech-dedicated hedge funds.

“Institutions went into game-theory mode: if the price steps, we need to be there,” another banker said.

Still, Scaringe indicated he had hand-selected allocations, suggesting this was a dirty auction and not just a matter who was prepared to pay the highest price.

Of course, some credit for the IPO’s success has to go Tesla’s Elon Musk and the trail he has blazed (turns out he has been selling stock in recent days), though Scaringe (and key backer and Musk’s space rival Jeff Bezos) will be hoping for a less eventful journey as a public company.

Though deals of this magnitude are rare, bankers do think there could be more of them over the next year or two as more seasoned unicorns come to market.

Expensive?

Subscription-based expense management software firm Expensify added to the brighter tone in the IPO market (in an otherwise tough day for tech stocks) by surging more than 50% in its debut Nasdaq session today.

Like Rivian and despite no sign of Morgan Stanley’s or Goldman Sachs’ fingerprints on the deal, Expensify employed the hybrid auction/direct order entry format to set the price. Still, the impact that had on the outcome was debatable since it didn’t exactly dampen aftermarket performance.

Using their own technology, JP Morgan, Citigroup and Bank of America last night priced 9.7m Expensify shares, including 7.1m from selling shareholders, at $27, the top of the $25–$27 range. In response to strong early demand, the syndicate increased the range from $23–$25 earlier this year.

The stock opened at $39.75 and traded up to close at $41.06 for a 52.1% gain.

The final IPO terms valued Expensify at about $2.6bn rising to about $4bn at today’s close or about 35x EV/sales on a trailing basis.

Founded in 2008 by David Barrett (a man who wears his politics on his sleeve), Expensify offers cloud-based software that enables its 660,000-plus paid members to automate their expense management by snapping a photo of receipts to sync with accounting software for automatic tracking and payment.

Members can also book travel and use the Expensify business credit card for faster reporting and reconciliation. They can also create and send invoices and split bills and request personal payments.

Blistering pace

Despite stock market indexes at record levels, or because of this, long-only investors are skittish heading into year-end at the same time private equity and venture sponsors are looking to aggressively crystallize gains.

The stampede to sell has backers of six companies that have gone public over the past year seeking this evening to price $1.1bn worth of follow-on stock sales.

“Everyone under the sun is coming to market,” said one ECM banker. “(But) investment committees at many mutual fund complexes are nervous about the market.

“A lot of these deals are not viewed as must-own. There aren’t catalysts that are going to lift these stock before year-end.

“That is forcing us to rely more upon hedge funds to get these deals, and that comes at price.”

The catalyst for some is Q3 earnings, but those positives are baked into the stock.

First Advantage, the screening software provider that went public in June (at $15.00), fell 10.6% to $20.56 in the past two sessions while publicly marketing the secondary sale of 15m shares. This was despite strong quarterly earnings leading up to the deal’s launch.

The offering, jointly led by Barclays and Bank of America, saw Silver Lake reduce its stake to 60.7% from 72.4%, but leaving a still sizable overhang.

The deal comes inside lock-up, but more lenient exemptions have been granted and First Advantage is exceeded expectations.

First Advantage shares spiked 14.6% when it reported Q2 earnings in August, and rose another 9.3% on Q3 earnings reported pre-open Monday, only to recalibrate when word of the stock sale hit late Monday.

First Advantage’s Q3 adjusted Ebitda and revenue of $63.9m and $192.9m easily exceeded the $50.3m and $171.6m consensus. This is a high cashflow story that is benefiting from increased hiring activity and the need to run background checks.

Like many industry verticals that have been introduced to public markets this year, ID/screening software is new, emerging investable opportunity, and one that (not surprisingly) does not lack options beyond First Advantage.

“We got a nice lift heading into the launch,” said the banker. “First Advantage is perceived by many to be the market leader, but there’s still a lot of investors not following this sector.”

Following in the footsteps of First Advantage, Goldman Sachs-backed background check provider Sterling Check (+11.9%) went public in September and the General Atlantic-backed HireRight (-3.7%) provided yet another option when it went public in October.

With so many options, perhaps now is not the time to ask investors to write checks on new investments.

The higher costs of sponsor exits is evident. Of the six secondary sell-downs due to price this evening, four fell double-digit percentages over the marketing period, and a fifth was down 9.6%.

Need to Know

Only KnowBe4, a private equity-backed cybersecurity specialist that went public in April, benefited from marketing, and then only eking out a 1.1% gain to close today’s session at $20.56.

The KnowBe4 secondary sale of 7m shares, a thin 4.1% stake, saw Elephant Partners, KKR and an affiliate of Goldman Sachs reduce their stakes to 22.3%, 15.7% and 6.9%.

Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Bank of America and KKR were joint books, a little bit of home cooking though notably this is a first-time follow-on that coincides with the November 9 expiry of the IPO lock-up.

Diversification not needed

Diversey, a manufacturer of hygienic products for hospitals and the hospitality industry, seemed precariously close to “breaking the IPO bank” as its shares fell 11.1% to $15.12 over the two days 15m shares were being marketed on behalf of Bain Capital.

Bain, which purchased the business in 2017 took it public in March, reduced its stake to 74.5% from 78.5%.

The $692.3m IPO priced at $15.00 was all-primary and used to repay debt, so this is the first chance Bain has had to sell stock.

Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, which were joint books on the IPO and are jointly running tonight’s follow-on, may be put in the uncomfortable position of defending the IPO a second time.

Apria, the Blackstone-backed in-home healthcare provider, saw similarly tepid investor receptivity for its all-secondary of 4.5m shares, already the second sell-down since its IPO in February.

Apria fell 9.6% over the two-day marketing period to $32.54, comfortably above both the $27.00 price on a similarly sized sale by Blackstone in June and the $20.00 IPO price.

Citigroup and Goldman Sachs were joint books, a notable narrowing of the underwriting syndicate from the earlier deals.

European Wax Centers, the General Atlantic-backed bikini-wax store operator, shaved off 13.2% to $26.83 while marketing its first-time follow-on, and medical device-marker 908 Devices’ sellers were evaluating options after a 16.6% decline while marketing 2.8m secondary shares.

The average file-to-last sale sell-off on tonight’s secondary sales was 10%.

Money-hungry Mirati

In a two-horse race to develop a promising cancer drug, Mirati Therapeutics is viewed as a distant second, though the race is not over and the potential of its cancer drug has yet to be determined.

Mirati returned to ECM this evening for $500m of fresh capital to help fund Phase III trials on its cancer drug, as well other drugs that at earlier stages of development.

Shares of Mirati plunged 11.4% to $148.77 while the fixed-size offering was marketed by Goldman Sachs, SVB Leerink and Cowen for one day today. Raising equity is almost an annual ritual for Mirati, which raised $875m from a follow-on stock sale in October last year at $202.00.

Tonight’s raise adds to a $1.1bn cash pile at September 30.

The stock’s underperformance is partly due to the approval of Amgen’s cancer drug in May that blocks proteins that contribute to cancer.

Mirati plans to submit its application for a competing drug with the FDA by the end of the year, specifically to treat non-small cell lung cancer. It is conducting Phase III trials on that same drug in combination with Eli Lilly’s Erbitux for colorectal cancer.

The company is also in the midst of a management restructuring.

In September, Mirati tapped David Meek as CEO to lead the commercial launch of its cancer drug, replacing Mirati founder Charles Baum who is staying on as president and head of R&D.

Mirati’s COO and chief science officer both stepped down from their posts earlier this month, with Meek and Baum expanding filling their roles.

Mirati is still looking for a new CFO.

The abrupt management changes may have spooked some investors. The long term opportunity for Mirati’s lead drug is another a point of concern.

Investors are still a few years away from a payoff. The management upheaval comes as analysts have Mirati hemorrhaging some $1.3bn of adjusted Ebitda over the next two years with revenue only gradually ramping to $250m in 2023, according to Refinitiv data.

Getting the timing right

SiTime, a maker of silicon-based timing products used in electronic devices, took advantage of the strength of the chip stocks to price a $450m follow-on stock sale late night.

After a day of marketing, a syndicate led by Barclays, Credit Suisse and Stifel priced the sale of 2m shares, including 1m primary and 1m from Japanese-based major shareholder MegaChips, at $225.00.

The offering, representing nearly 10% of the company, came at a hefty 22.8% file-to-offer discount, though SiTime shares had more than doubled in the past year leading into the deal and are up massively since the company went public at just $13.00 in November 2019.

In today's aftermarket, the shares closed at $228.36 or slightly above the offering price.

"There was a nice mix of new and existing investors," one banker close to the deal said, noting SiTime was a beneficiary of the strong chip market but not directly impacted by chip shortages.

MegaChips is left with a 24.7% stake and can sell more in 60 days.

Beauty treatment

Private equity firm KKR & Co disposed of its remaining 2.4% stake in Coty via a Morgan Stanley-led $210m unregistered block trade last night, a deal the beauty products firm said would “further simplify” its capital structure and conserve cash.

Morgan Stanley reoffered 20m Coty shares at $10.50, inside the $10.35–$10.81 range and a 2.9% discount to last sale.

Coty, probably best known for its $600m purchase of a controlling stake in Kylie Jenner’s Kylie Cosmetics in late 2019, struggled to hold its ground in today’s aftermarket, closing at $10.49.

Following three separate sales over the past three months and coming in the wake of Monday’s 15% surge in Coty’s share price after upbeat earnings, KKR converted its remaining holdings of convertible preferred shares into common stock before offloading them via the block.

The latest sale leaves Coty with $146m of convertible preferred shares outstanding, or the equivalent of 23m shares. These are held by Coty chairman Peter Harf, also a partner of Coty’s controlling shareholder, Dutch/German privately held investment firm JAB.

The price of the latest block was above the $8.39 mark at which KKR offloaded 50m Coty shares in early September, also via a Morgan Stanley block trade (the reoffer price was $8.53 according to our records).

KKR took a $1bn stake in Coty last year as part of a deal that also saw the private equity firm buy 60% of the Wella haircare business.

More recently, Coty sold additional smaller stakes in the Wella haircare brand to KKR in exchange for some of KKR's remaining convertible preferreds (part of that deal was announced earlier this week).

JAB, which owns 56.8% of Coty at last count (prior to the latest deal), has had a busy week already, yesterday striking a deal with big-name restaurateur Danny Meyer to help take Panera Bread public in the coming months.

Panera said in a press release yesterday it intended to file a draft registration statement for the IPO, suggesting it is still several months away.

Fashion victim

Just in time for the holiday shopping season, Lulu’s Fashion House is close to securing roughly $90m of new funding this evening from its IPO, though that is less than hoped.

Goldman Sachs, Bank of America and Jefferies stitched together a book of demand by anchoring the sale of 5.75m new shares at $16.00, the bottom of a $16–$18, they communicated ahead of the market open today.

At $16.00, the IPO values Lulu’s around $600m on a fully diluted basis.

The online fashion retailer follows some tepid debuts by aka Brands (+7.7%) and Rent-the-Runway (18.6%).

Still, Lulu’s high growth and online-only platform made for positive comparisons to Revolve, whose shares have soared 157% this year.

Revolve shares dipped 4.65% today to $80.10.

Lulu’s is profitable. It expects to report a net profit of $3.3m–$3.9m from revenue of $104.5m–$106.3m in Q3, up from a net profit of $0.3m from $54.5m of revenue in the same quarter last year.

In addition to saving money on rent, Lulu’s online platform allows it to be more flexible than a brick-and-mortar retailers.

Since Lulu’s does not have to hold a large inventory of its products, it can respond quickly to ever-changing fashion trends.

Lulu’s also saves money by marketing online to its 7.5m followers on social media, who are mostly Millennial and Gen Z women.

Its social media following helped give rise to 2.5m active customers as of October 3, of which 65% were repeat customers in Q3.

Links

Smart building/access control technology firm Brivo to go public via $808m merger with Crown PropTech Acquisitions.

Li’s FWD considers shifting US IPO to Hong Kong.

Hershey pays $1.2bn for Dot’s Pretzels/Pretzels Inc (funded with cash on hand and short-term borrowings).

Moderna and US National Institutes of Health squabble over who invented Covid-19 vaccine.

Restaurant software firm Presto announces SPAC merger with CCM Acquisition.

Priced

Monday

Apeiron Capit al Investment (US, SPAC) – $150m IPO. 15m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. BRLY. NYSE “APN U”. Joel Shulman. Financial services/wealth management. 12 months. 102% in trust.

DP Cap Acquisition I (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. COWN. Nasdaq “DPCSU”. Data Point Capital. Tech. 18 months. 102% in trust.

Hertz Global (US, car rental) – $1.3bn Nasdaq IPO. 44.52m shares (100% sec) at $29.00 versus $25-$29 marketing. GS, JPM, MS, BARC, DB. Nasdaq “HTZ”. Upsized from 37.1m shares. Uplisting from OTC shares trading under “HTZZ” at $25.70 at file and $35.06 at launch. Hertz bought back $300m of stock (10.34m shares) versus $250m-$500m indicated at launch.

Hunt Companies Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. JEFF. NYSE “HTAQ.U”. Hunt Companies (Chris Hunt, Jim Hunt). Proptech. 12 months. 101.5% in trust.

Ping Identity (US, software) – $282.5m Block. 10m shares (100% sec) at $28.25 versus $28.25-$28.75 marketing and $29.25 last sale. MS. Last block priced at $23.85 in August.

Playa Hotels & Resorts (US, hotels) – $69.7m Block. 8.35m shares (100% sec) at $8.35 versus $8.25-$8.45 marketing versus $8.60 last sale. BOFA. Farallon Capital Management is selling shareholder.

Surgery Partners (US, surgery centers) – $279m FO. 6m shares (100% prim) at $46.50 versus $48.18 last sale and $50.10 at launch. BOFA, JPM, JEFF. Upsized from 5m shares.

Talos Energy (US, E&P) – $73.8m Block. 6m shares (100% sec) at $12.30 versus $13.05 last sale. JPM.

Third Coast Bancshares (US, bank) – $87.5m IPO. 3.5m shares (100% prim) at $25.00 versus $24-$26 marketing. STPH, PS, DB. Nasdaq “TCBX”. Upsized from 3m shares.

Tuesday

Amyris (US, bioengineered additives) – $600m 5y cvt priced at 1.5%, up 35% versus 1.5%-2% and 30%-35% marketing. JPM, COWN, OPCO, MS. Upsized from $400m.

Arena Fortify Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $150m IPO. 15m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-third warrant. COWN, INTRP. Nasdaq “AFACU”. Arena Investors, Fortify Energy Management. Natural resources. 15 months, 102% in trust.

Ascendant Digital Acquisition III (US, SPAC) – $261m IPO. 26.1m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. GS. NYSE “ACDI.U”. Upsized from $250m. David Gomberg. TMT. 15 months, 102% in trust. Seven institutions indicated for $136.5m combined for portion of sponsor economics. Japan NEXON $90m FPA.

Blockchain Coinvestors Acquistion I (US, SPAC) – $261m IPO. 26.1m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. CANT, MOLS. Nasdaq “BCSA.U”. Matthew Le Merle, Lou Kerner, Alison Davis. Fintech. Unit structure revised from one-third warrant at launch. 18 months. 100% in trust.

Chain Bridge I (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. COWN, WF. Nasdaq “CBRGU”. Chain Group (Christopher Darby, Micahel Rolnick). Tech, cybersecurity. 18 months. 102% in trust. Franklin Templeton FPA for $40m.

Chinook Therapeutics (US, biotech) – $159.6m FO. 11.4m shares (100% prim) at $14.00 versus $14.51 last sale and $14.19 at launch. SVBL, EVER. Upsized from 6m shares. Includes pre-funded warrants.

CI&T (Brazil, software development) – $195.7m IPO. 13m shares (85% prim, 15% sec) at $15.00 versus $15-$17 marketing. GS, CITI, JPM, MS. NYSE “CINT”. Downsized from 19.4m shares at $17-$19.

Cryoport (US, biologics transportation services) – $350m 5y cvt priced at 0.75%, up 45% versus 75%-1.25% and 40%-45% marketing. JEFF, SVBL. Upsized from $300m. Concurrent registered direct stock placement. Using combined proceeds to repurchase portion of 3% CB due 2025.

Expensify (US, enterprise software) – $262.7m IPO. 9.7m shares (27% prim, 73% sec) at $27.00 versus $25-$27 marketing. JPM, CITI, BOFA. Nasdaq “EXFY”. Range increased from $23-$25.

Kimbell Royalty Partners (US, E&P royalty trust) – $52.5m ABB. 3.75m units (100% prim) at $14.00 versus $14.00-$14.50 marketing and $15.35 last sale. CITI, RJ.

RCF Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. CITI, BARC. NYSE “RCFA.U”. Resource Capital Funds. Energy transition. 18 months. 102% in trust.

Rivian Automotive (US, electric vehicles) – $11.9bn IPO. 153m shares (100% prim) at $78.00 versus $72-$74 marketing. MS, GS, JPM. Nasdaq “RIVN”. Upsized from 135m shares, range increased from $57-$62. Cornerstone investors indicated for $5bn. 7% DSP to US customers with outstanding pre-orders as of September 30.

SiTime (US, semiconductors) – $450m. 2m shares (50% prim, 50% sec) at $225.00 versus $243.94 last sale and $291.34 at launch. BARC, CS, STFL.

Calendar

November 10: MGP Ingredients (US, distilled spirits) – $175m 20y, put-five cvt marketed at 1.5%-2%, up 35%-40%. WF, TRST, ALLN.

November 10: Mirati Therapeutics (US, biotech) – $500m FO. Fixed size (100% prim) versus $167.84 at launch. GS, SVBL, COWN.

November 10: 908 Devices (US, medical devices) – $106.6m FO. 2.75m shares (100% prim) versus $38.77 last sale. COWN, SVBL, WBLR, STFL. Went public at $20.00 in December 2020.

November 10: Apria (US, home healthcare) – $162m FO. 4.5m shares (100% sec) versus $35.99 at launch. CITI, GS. Went public at $20.00 in February, priced first-time follow-on at $27 in June.

November 10: Backblaze (US, software) – $106.3m IPO. 6.25m shares (100% prim) at $15-$17. OPCO, WBLR, RJ. Nasdaq “BLZE”. 5% DSP.

November 10: Diversey (US, specialty chemicals) – $255.2m FO. 15m shares (100% prim) versus $17.01 at launch. CITI, MS. Went public at $15.00 in March.

November 10: European Wax Centers (US, retail) – $161.3m FO. 5.2m shares (45% prim, 55% sec) versus $30.92 at launch. MS, BOFA, JEFF. Went public at $17.00 in August.

November 10: First Advantage (US, screening services) – $345m FO. 15m shares (100% sec) versus $23.00 at launch. BARC, BOFA, CITI, EVER, JEFF, RBC, STFL, HSBC. Went public at $15.00 in June.

November 10: Hain Celestial (US, organic food products) – $575.6m Block. 12.38m shares (100% sec) at $45.50-$46.50 versus $48.09. MS. Company repurchasing 1.7m shares directly from selling shareholder Engaged Capital.

November 10: KnowBe4 (US, cybersecurity) – $182m FO. 7m shares (100% sec) versus $26.00 at launch. MS, GS, BOFA, KKR. Went public at $16.00 in April.

November 10: Lulu’s Fashion Lounge (US, retailer) – $109.3m IPO. 5.75m shares (100% prim) at $16-$19. GS, BOFA, JEFF.Nasdaq “LVLU”. DSP. Principal Global indicating for $15m.

November 10: Mynaric (Germany, laser communications) – $69.9m Nasdaq IPO. 4m ADSs (100% prim) versus €60.40/$17.48 launch reference. CS, JEFF, CGEN. Nasdaq “MYNA”. Trades on Frankfurt Stock Exchange “MOY”. Each ADS represents one-quarter ordinary share.

November 10: Vaxxinity (US, biotech) – $107.2m IPO. 6.7m shares (100% prim) at $14-$16. BOFA, JEFF, EVER. Nasdaq “VAXX”.

November 10: Weave Communications (US, software) – $140m IPO. 5m shares (100% prim) at $25-$28. GS, BOFA, CITI. NYSE “WEAV”. Pelion Ventures and Crosslink Capital indicating for $20m of offering.

November 11: 3D Systems (US, 3D printers) – $350m 5y cvt marketed at 0%-0.5%, up 35%-40%. GS.

November 11: Eneti (Monaco, shipping) – $200m FO. Number of shares TBD (100% prim) versus $14.21 at launch. CITI, DNB, BTIG, NOM. Former Scorpio Bulkers. Scorpio, a related party, has expressed an interest in buying $30m of shares in the offering.

Week of November 15: Coveo Solutions (Canada, AI software) – C$215m ($172.6m) IPO. 14.33m-$16.54m shares (100% prim) at C$13-$15. BMO, BOFA, RBC, UBS. TSX “CVO”.

Week of November 15: Definity Financial (Canada, insurance) – C$1.25bn ($1bn) IPO. 56.8m-65.8m shares (100% prim) at C$19-$22. BMO, RBC, BARC, SCOT, TD. TSX “DFY”.

November 16: Braze (US, software) – $480m IPO. 8m shares (84% prim, 16% sec) at $55-$60. GS, JPM, BARC, PS, WBLR. Nasdaq “BRZE”.

November 16: Iris Energy (Australia, bitcoin mining) – $223.3m IPO. 8.3m shares (100% prim) at $25-$27. JPM, CGEN, CITI. Nasdaq “IREN”.

November 16: Sono Motors (Germany, electric vehicles) – $160m IPO. 10m (100% prim) at $14-$16. BRBG. Nasdaq “SEV”.
